place_description: I moved to NYC to pursue a Master's in Information Systems with a focus in urban tech at Cornell Tech. Here, I got to work on some cool projects that deepened my understanding of emerging technologies and urban planning.

I spent my early twenties in Berkeley, where I earned a B.A. in Data Science and Economics from the University of California, Berkeley. 

Living in the long shadow of Silicon Valley shaped my understanding of how the world works and who runs it.

Still, the sun hits different in California. 

Cue Phantom Planet's "California."

I spent my early twenties in Oakland, California, where I began my career at an insurance firm. 

Cue Childish Gambino's "III. Telegraph Ave."

While I never lived in San Francisco, the city left a lasting impression on me. I spent the pandemic years here and observed how a city built around tech can sometimes leave other industries and institutions by the wayside. Be that as it may, it was here that I first explored public transit data and open-source urban analytics, with much of my early work focused on the Bay Area Rapid Transit (BART) system.
Mumbai is where my parents live, so it is the closest to a home. I completed my high school years here!
I got to work on a cool taxonomy project when I was a research asssitant at UC Berkeley's Essig Museum of Entomology. A couple years later, I visited Oahu and Maui with some friends.

My parents and I lived in Yokohama for two years. I remember riding on the local subways and bullet trains with my mom. Looking back, this is probably where my appreciation for public transit first began. .

After Japan, my parents and I moved to Singapore. It's a small country, so I know it's hard to compare to places like the U.S. or India, but it showed me what's possible when a city is thoughtfully planned.

After Singapore, my parents and I moved to Sydneyâ€”a different ballgame altogether. The car-centric lifestyle was a bit tough for my mom and me, since we were used to walking everywhere. It felt isolating after living in such pedestrian-friendly cities, but it was also one of the most beautiful places I've ever seen.
I was selected as a student assistant for ESRI's User Conference, one of the world's largest GIS conferences, held in San Diego, California.
I was selected as a student assistant for ESRI's Developer & Technology Summit in Palm Springs, California. I really enjoyed Palm Springs!

As a product analyst for an insurance firm, I was responsible for Personal Lines Auto and Property insurance for Arizona, Nevada, and Utah. While I never got to visit these states, I did get to work on some cool projects that helped me understand the ins and outs of the insurance industry.

As a product analyst for an insurance firm, I was responsible for Personal Lines Auto and Property insurance for Arizona, Nevada, and Utah. While I never got to visit these states, I did get to work on some cool projects that helped me understand the ins and outs of the insurance industry.

As a product analyst for an insurance firm, I was responsible for Personal Lines Auto and Property insurance for Arizona, Nevada, and Utah. While I never got to visit these states, I did get to work on some cool projects that helped me understand the ins and outs of the insurance industry.
My office was in Walnut Creek when I worked as a product analyst at an insurance firm.
Cornell Tech's campus is located on Roosevelt Island, a thing strip of land island in the East River between Manhattan and Queens. This is also where I live.

I identified optimal tree planting locations using land surface temperature data from Sentinel EO Hub's Landsat 8 LIDAR (shown in red) and Michael Treglia's 'practical canopy' framework, which considers land use, cover, and infrastructure constraints (shown in green). This map presents the results of that analysis for BK11 community district.

I identified optimal tree planting locations using land surface temperature data (Sentinel EO Hub's Landsat 8 LIDAR) and Michael Treglia's 'practical canopy' framework, which considers land use, cover, and infrastructure constraints. This map presents the results of that analysis for BK17 community district.

I identified optimal tree planting locations using land surface temperature data from Sentinel EO Hub's Landsat 8 LIDAR (shown in red) and Michael Treglia's 'practical canopy' framework, which considers land use, cover, and infrastructure constraints (shown in green). This map presents the results of that analysis for BX5 community district.

I identified optimal tree planting locations using land surface temperature data from Sentinel EO Hub's Landsat 8 LIDAR (shown in red) and Michael Treglia's 'practical canopy' framework, which considers land use, cover, and infrastructure constraints (shown in green). This map presents the results of that analysis for MN10 community district.

I identified optimal tree planting locations using land surface temperature data from Sentinel EO Hub's Landsat 8 LIDAR (shown in red) and Michael Treglia's 'practical canopy' framework, which considers land use, cover, and infrastructure constraints (shown in green). This map presents the results of that analysis for QN2 community district.

I identified optimal tree planting locations in the five boroughs of NYC using land surface temperature data from Sentinel EO Hub's Landsat 8 LIDAR (shown in red) and Michael Treglia's 'practical canopy' framework, which considers land use, cover, and infrastructure constraints (shown in green). This map shows the two metrics across NYC.

I got to visit New Zealand with my parents. I really loved this country. It is fascinating how they rebuilt Christchurch after the 2011 earthquake. Look at the video I shot of Border Collie and Hunt Away dogs herding sheep in Agrodome, Rotorua in the North Island!
